I interpret "an armed group from Afghanistan" as ruling out the Islamic State.  The question then is whether the Afghan Taliban or the Haqqani Network will kill 1000+ civilians by June 30, 2018.  Taliban and Haqqani attacks on security forces sadly often result in collateral damage including loss of civilian life, but usually only in small numbers. Since both groups (especially the Taliban) rely somewhat on local tribal communities for support, and wish to avoid taking any actions that would compel the United States and NATO to redeploy increased numbers of troops back to Afghanistan, it would be a strategically disastrous move by either group to systematically kill 1000+ Afghan civilians.

The taliban and other revolutionary groups are not going to give up or leave until they have regained power.   In a conflict of this nature both the opposing military as well as the civilian population are targets.   This strategy of Total War means you must beat the opposing forces as well as demoralize to the point of surrender the civilian population.  Some day the Americans and NATO will leave.  I know what side I would want to have been on if I was going to be left behind.
There are three groups capable of this if they feel aggrieved enough: Taliban, IS, and the government or militias loosely tied to the government

The Hazara people of Afghanistan appear to be the group most at risk for genocide.  The humans of that region of earth hold onto ethnic grudges for centuries.  The most recent documented genocide in Afghanistan was of the Hazara people in the late nineteenth century.  Large scale violence against the ethnic group has stopped, but the Pashtun people still hold onto their hatred.  I believe the Taliban or run of the mill Pashtun Afghani would participate in a genocide of the Hazaras, but the opportunity has yet to present itself, coupled with the fact they are busy with an insurgency.  In my estimation, there are too many moving parts and eyeballs for the systematic killing of 1,000 or more Afghani civilians.
One gets the impression that the Early Warning people will be sorely disappointed if a whole lot of people don't get killed.  If that's what they want, their definition is probably too narrow.
